properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A stream of moisture from the Pacific continues to push in to southwestern Alberta, and precipitation continues to fall in the Rockies. Near Crowsnest Pass, precipitation is falling as wet snow or rain. Snowfall amounts of 5-10 cm is possible near the British Columbia border. This precipitation is expected to continue through today and tonight before the system moves eastward. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-22T03:32:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T11:33:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0947473055.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snowfall is expected to continue in Banff National Park through Saturday. Total amounts will vary through the region, but generally amounts will range from 20 to 30 centimetres by Saturday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T14:31:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-20T22:32:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1562713308.2019
Area: Clearwater Co. near Siffleur Wilderness Area, Banff Nat. Park near Saskatchewan River Crossing, Banff Nat. Park near Lake Louise, Banff Nat. Park near Banff
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts approaching 50 cm is possible by Saturday night. Another push of moisture is expected today with 10 to 20 cm possible. This would bring total two day accumulations up to 45 cm by Saturday night. The heaviest snow is expected to fall south of Saskatchewan River Crossing. Somewhat lesser amounts totalling 30 cm are possible from Saskatchewan River Crossing north to the Columbia Icefield area. North of the Columbia Icefield area minimal snowfall accumulations are expected today. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-22T03:31:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T11:32:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0463968790.2019
Area: Highway 93 South - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 North - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. An area of widespread fog has developed through portions of west-central Saskatchewan this morning. The fog will produce areas of near-zero visibilities at times. Conditions will gradually improve through the morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T20:01:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T10:41:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3530716919.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Snowfall is expected to continue in Banff National Park and Kananaskis before it tapers off Sunday morning. Total amounts will vary through the region, but generally amounts will range from 20 to 30 centimetres by Sunday morning with locally higher amounts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 50 and minus 55. Extreme cold conditions are expected to persist through the weekend. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A strong Pacific frontal system continues to inundate the Fraser Valley with heavy rain. Additional rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are expected before the rain eases on Saturday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 50. A strong arctic ridge of high pressure across northern Yukon will give temperatures near minus 41 tonight through the weekend. A gentle breeze at times will result in wind chill values reaching minus 50. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T16:01:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T00:02:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2100960888.2019

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Snow to continue tonight. A frontal system has stalled over southern BC. A steady stream of moisture making its way into the BC Interior has brought heavy snow to the Similkameen today. As of 3pm PST, 18 cm of snow has been reported at the Princeton Airport thus far today. An additional 5 to 10 cm is expected tonight. Snow should ease to flurries after midnight and continue much of Saturday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-21T16:00:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T00:01:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3345035513.2019
Area: Similkameen

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. Milder air has settled in over southern Kootenay and many locales continue to report rain or a mix of wet snow and rain. Northern portions of Arrow Slocan, including Shelter and Galena Bays will continue to see wet snow tonight and tomorrow morning with an additional 5 to 10 cm possible tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain for the eastern portions of the Elk Valley. A frontal system is currently stalled over southern BC. With a steady stream of moisture and mild temperatures, heavy rain is expected to continue over parts of the Elk Valley through today. Close to 60 mm of rain has been reported near Morrissey. Areas near Fernie and Morissey can expect additional rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-22T03:46:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-21T11:56:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0068018533.2019
Area: Elk Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Milder air has settled over southern portions of the Kootenay, and many locations are reporting rain or a mix of rain and snow. Northern most communities, including Radium Hot Springs and Edgewater, remain at or slightly below freezing and will continue to receive snow tonight and at least into Saturday morning. An additional 10 cm of snow is possible by morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
